candidates.title: Cliquerator: Switch non_core_nodes as Vec

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
Candidates currently store noncore nodes as a Map from node type ids. This is pretty memory inefficient and results in extra work copying memory when we're cloning candidates for the next generation.

Switched them to just keep a vec of the counts of nodes by type.

candidates.title: Replace rustc-serialize with serde_json

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
`rustc-serialize` is deprecated for `serde`, and by extension, `serde_json`.

This PR updates dachshund to serde.

candidates.title: Update dependencies

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
Updates outdated dependencies, except for clap which has known breaking changes where I don't know the cli tools enough to know the differences.

Updating `rand` from 0.6 to 0.8 needed a small fix to use a range instead of two values.

candidates.title: Clippy fixes; use 2021 edition

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
Hello! Just a few things I've noticed that might help with code quality:
 - Set edition to 2021. Didn't see a MSRV so I just updated y'all from 2018.
 - Ran `cargo +nightly clippy --fix`, which fixed a bunch of lints.
 - Simplified `set_neigbhorhood`<sub>[sic]</sub>`_with_hint` to fix another clippy lint.

Note that there are additional clippy lints but those required more time investment.

candidates.title: Cliquerator Optimizations

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
These optimizations (mainly the changes to the beam) improve performance of the clique_miner by ~45% on dense benchmarks.

Includes a new test to confirm that one_step_search actually produces the best ( according to the heuristic ) candidates. Previously this was untested because all the toy examples were too small.

candidates.title: Switch to RoaringBitmap for Typed Graphs; Labeled Graphs

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
This diff switches the storage for TypedGraphs' neighborhoods, etc, to use RoaringBitmaps instead of FxHashMaps. This vastly improves the performance of count_ties_with_ids, at the expense of slightly more expensive graph build times. For some typical workloads, this nets out to a ~4x speed up.

In order to do this we needed to add a bunch of  type bounds (this would be simpler if this change were adopted across all graph types) and a bunch of code to support turning Node Labels (used for input and output) into internal Node indexes 0...n.

candidates.title: Implemented K-Peaks algorithm and created test cases

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body: Added a k_peaks.rs file which contains function to compute k-peaks and mountain assignments for each node. Also created a test case in simple_graph.rs.

candidates.title: Added Connected Component Extractor

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
A very simple connected component extractor for undirected graphs. Input is `(graph_id, node_id_1, node_id_2)`, output is `(graph_id, component_id, node_id)`.

To test:

```
cargo +nightly build
cat example.txt | cut -d$'\t' -f1-3 | ./target/debug/connected_component_extractor
```

candidates.title: Added SimpleUndirectedGraphBuilderWithCliques / graph builder functions now attach to object

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body: This PR sets up a new kind of builder for a simple undirected graph, one that also adds cliques to e.g. an Erdos-Renyi random graph -- this is the first example of a more sophisticated graph generation process. Doing so requires us to keep some state in the `GraphBuilder` struct. From now on graph builder functions attach to the GraphBuilder object -- those structs ceasing to be pure convenience-driven collections of functions.

candidates.title: Switch Nodes Map to fxhash and Cache non_core_counts on Candidate

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
Working with some sample benchmarks that seed with relatively large cliques, I noticed that calculating the non_core_diversity score was among the most expensive parts of clique mining because it required looking up the type of every node in the candidate each time we went to score a node.

This PR contains 2 changes:

I replaced the nodes hashmap with fxhash, a crate that provides drop in replacements for collections::HashMap and HashSet. This hash function is much faster (thanks to not guaranteeing that it's cryptographically secure). The only required change was updating the types and to initialize with ::default() instead of ::new(). My recommendation is to gradually adopt this across the crate, starting with hot sections of the code.

Secondly, I added another attribute on candidate to record the counts of each noncore type and updated them incrementally rather than recalculating them from scratch each time we score a candidate.

These two improvements together dropped the time on the large clique benchmark by ~35%.

repo.name: dachshund
repo.description: Dachshund is a graph mining library written in Rust. It provides high performance data structures for multiple kinds of graphs, from simple undirected graphs to typed hypergraphs. Dachshund also provides algorithms for common tasks for graph mining and analysis, ranging from shortest paths to graph spectral analysis.
